title: 115_s224
content: The "Child Interstate Abortion Notification Act" is cited as the short title. Part I of title 18, United States Code, is amended to include a new chapter on the transportation of minors in circumvention of certain laws relating to abortion. The "Child Interstate Abortion Notification Act" introduces regulations on transporting minors across state lines for abortions, in violation of parental involvement laws. Offenders face fines or imprisonment. The "Child Interstate Abortion Notification Act" prohibits minors from obtaining abortions in a different state or country without parental consent or judicial authorization, except in cases of life-endangering conditions. The "Child Interstate Abortion Notification Act" prohibits minors from getting abortions in another state without parental consent, except in life-threatening situations. Minors and parents cannot be prosecuted for violating this law. An affirmative defense is available if the defendant believed parental consent had been obtained before the abortion. The "Child Interstate Abortion Notification Act" requires parental involvement in a minor's abortion decision, unless waived by a court in the minor's state of residence. Parents can seek civil action for harm caused by a violation of the law, except in cases of incest. The act defines abortion as the intentional use of any instrument or substance for termination. The "Child Interstate Abortion Notification Act" defines abortion as the intentional use of any instrument, medicine, drug, or substance to terminate a pregnancy, with exceptions for preserving the life or health of the child. It also defines a law requiring parental involvement in a minor's abortion decision as one that mandates parental notification or consent before the procedure. The term 'minor' refers to an individual who is not older than the maximum age requiring parental notification or consent for abortion. The term 'parent' includes a parent, guardian, legal custodian, or an individual standing in loco parentis with care and control of the minor. The term 'minor' refers to an individual who is not older than the maximum age requiring parental notification or consent for abortion. A 'parent' includes someone with care and control of the minor, with whom the minor resides regularly, and who is designated by law for notification or consent. The term 'State' includes the District of Columbia, any commonwealth, possession, territory of the United States, and any Indian tribe or reservation. Section 2432 addresses the transportation of minors in circumvention of laws related to abortion and incest. Offense: Anyone who commits incest with a minor and transports them across state lines for an abortion will face fines or imprisonment. Definitions for 'abortion', 'minor', and 'State' are as defined in section 2435. SEC. 3. CHILD INTERSTATE ABORTION NOTIFICATION. Part I of title 18, United States Code, is amended to include CHAPTER 117B--CHILD INTERSTATE ABORTION NOTIFICATION. Sec. 2435 of the Child Interstate Abortion Notification law imposes fines or imprisonment on physicians who perform abortions on minors without parental notification. Physicians must provide at least 24 hours actual notice to a parent of the minor before performing the abortion. Constructive notice must be given to a parent if actual notice is not achieved after a reasonable effort. Exceptions to the notification requirement include compliance with state laws on parental involvement or court waivers of notification. The minor can procure an abortion if authorized by the State laws, declares abuse in a signed statement, or if the abortion is necessary to save her life due to physical conditions. The law requires parental notification or physical presence of a parent for a minor's abortion, with civil action available for violations. The term 'abortion' is defined as the intentional use of any method to kill an unborn child or terminate a pregnancy, with exceptions for live birth or preserving the child's life. 'Actual notice' is direct written notification by a physician or their agent, while 'constructive notice' is certified mail with return receipt. The term 'law requiring parental involvement in a minor's abortion decision' refers to a law that mandates parental notification or consent before an abortion is performed on a minor, with no alternative options for notification or consent from other individuals or entities. Delivery of notification is through certified mail with return receipt, deemed to have occurred 48 hours after mailing. The term 'minor' refers to an individual under 18 years old who is not emancipated under state law. The term 'parent' includes a parent, guardian, legal custodian, or an individual standing in loco parentis as determined by state law. The term 'physician' refers to a doctor of medicine authorized to practice by the state. The term 'physician' refers to a doctor authorized to practice medicine in the state, or any other person legally empowered to perform an abortion. The term 'State' includes the District of Columbia, commonwealths, territories of the United States, and Indian tribes or reservations. SEC. 4. CLERICAL AMENDMENT. The table of chapters in title 18, United States Code, is amended to include new items related to transportation of minors in circumvention of abortion laws and child interstate abortion notification. SEC. 5. SEVERABILITY AND EFFECTIVE DATE. The provisions of this Act are severable, and if any part is found unconstitutional, it will not affect the rest of the Act. The Act and its amendments will take effect 45 days after enactment.
